Fields.DialogueText: Hey, Captain!
Sure, but I'm not an expert on that sort of thing. I thought you already had a good handle on it.
Well, since we're going together, I want the world tour to be something that you can enjoy.
I'm sure that we'll have fun no matter what happens.
Still, I don't want to get so wrapped up in the things I enjoy that I miss things that you would like in turn.
Nevada... thanks.
Besides, I trust your management skills. You've led us through more than your share of scrapes, so you've earned a spot at the table. What's the most important thing we should consider?

Fields.MenuText: Packing is essential. We need enough supplies for any emergency, and enough room for additional purchases during the trip.
We need to plan out the routes well. A little spontaneity is good, but we also need to know where we're going.
The most important thing is figuring out how to carry out the road trip to begin with. Don't count your chickens before they hatch, as they say.

Fields.DialogueText: Can't forget the supplies! And don't worry if we run out. I'm an expert quartermaster and forager in a pinch.
Gotta strike that balance of long and memorable. Even I can't go everywhere and do everything!
Working on it, Captain! Ideally some way that doesn't involve flooding your country.
Well, in any case, it will be a lot of fun touring the world together.
It sure will. There's so much to see, and it's that much more exciting with the right person.
I just wonder how much will be left before the Morganas are finished off.
There's enough ruins I want to see. The Morganas won't make any more!
Then let's do our duty.
@BATTLE
Nevada! I didn't know you kept a diary.
This is no diary, Cap. Well, it's a record of where my head's at... but I think it's more of an itinerary.
Come down off that gun barrel so you can show me.
Thought you'd never ask!
Here I am! Actually, I wanted your input on some of it.
*ALARM*
Nice postcard you've got there, Nevada. The Moulin Rouge?
Only the finest cabaret in all of grand Paris!
Looks like it would be a lot of fun to see.
My thoughts exactly. Which is why Paris is high on the list for our road trip.
It's going to be tough getting through the streets, much less attending the theater.
Going to see a show will be a show of our own, won't it?

Fields.MenuText: I just said it would be tough. That doesn't stop us from trying.
Maybe you can audition for a dance there yourself.
When we go there, just make sure we have time for stops of my own as well. I've always wanted to see the Louvre.

Fields.DialogueText: Just like mining, you have to keep digging until you strike it rich.
Well, I can only get to Rouen by water. From there, we'll have to get creative!
That makes two of us! I can almost taste the history now...
Paris would be a nice stop on the journey. Hopefully the city will still be standing by the end of the war.
Don't worry. We'll make sure that the wonders of the world endure this storm. After all, we've got to have sights to see if we want to go sightseeing!
You're right. In that case, let's do our best to keep the Morganas on the run. Find any?
Some over to port. Better get ready.
@BATTLE
How are the engines looking?
They're taking some work to spruce up. Those last Morganas left some nasty scars, but I've got it under control. Hey, want some oil?
I'm not a Belle, Nevada.
Ah, too bad. Oil has such a fine taste to it. Actually, I believe that if humans had discovered oil first, they never would have gotten onto alcohol!
Refined oil didn't really exist back then.
Well, no time like the present! If you're worried about drinking it, I could always just sprinkle it on some tamales to get you used to it.

Fields.MenuText: I'm kind of worried that I'll catch fire.
But you like alcohol yourself, right?
Maybe some other time.

Fields.DialogueText: It's got less bite than whiskey. Just keep away from open flames!
I do, and it makes a good substitute. But you have never truly felt souped up until you've tasted some fine oil.
Good idea. I'll save that surprise meal for a special occasion.
Well, you have your own tastes, and I have mine. You're a terrific cook, though.
If I minimize risk anywhere in my life, cooking is it.
I just prefer to eat foods that I know I am comfortable with.
Oh, come on! Everyone likes spicing things up with surprises now and then.
Not always. For one, I would be a lot happier if these Morganas stopped paying us surprise visits.
@BATTLE
That wasn't quite what I meant...
A kitchen's like an ammo magazine, Captain. You've got to keep both stocked for any occasion!
What's the best timing for this?  Everything needs to run like clockwork...
What's the problem? Some sort of trick dance timing?
No, it's something else. Say, do you know any good ways to stay warm? Maybe heavy fur coats or something?
Why? The weather's been decent, so you don't need to worry about getting cold.
Yeah, but I'm wondering about for the road trip. Russia can get pretty cold in the winter, they say.
Russia? That was one of the last places I expected to turn up on the itinerary. Even if we set aside the... uh... political difficulties surrounding an American military vessel in the Soviet Union-
I don't, but we can't leave Russia out of the trip. The Trans-Siberian Railway covers over 5,700 miles. That's an experience of a lifetime. Just a really, really chilly one.

Fields.MenuText: Seriously, don't minimize the dangers of the cold. We don't know if your human form is susceptible to frostbite - but I know we don't want to find out.
I would think we'd want to aim for summer.
If you can get the ship to drive on land, the frost will be a piece of cake.

Fields.DialogueText: You also know that I can't back out of a challenge. It's a little risky, but it's such an adventure!
Yeah, only we need to time it just right. Bad timing's what did in the Donners, and they didn't have to go nearly as far as Napoleon.
I might have a future as an icebreaker after all!
Well, I do concede it would be a lot of fun. Assuming the people would be as easily managed as the environment.
I'm sure that things will warm up. We're all in this war together now. Once we defeat the Morganas, bright times are on their way.
Yeah, but first we need to get there. These ghosts don't make things easy.
@BATTLE
Wouldn't it be nice if they could break the ice for us? Might as well get some use out of them...
*ALARM*
Yeah, set those aside. We'll figure `em out when the time comes.
Sure.
The fact is, you generally don't like the cold.
Nevada! Are you okay?
Just grand, Captain. That shot just whizzed right by me, didn't it?
You're sure that you're okay?
Positive! Actually, it was kind of exciting how close it got that time.
Wait, you're actually happy that you almost got hurt?
Well, no, but I felt a thrill down my spine at the risk.

Fields.MenuText: I don't want you to get hurt.
That's kind of a dangerous lifestyle.
Just try to be careful, please. A lot is at stake here.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't worry.  I know this isn't any old round of Omaha. When push comes to shove, and I lose a hand here and there, I don't just throw in the cards. A few ghosts won't kill me.
But a fulfilling one, you have to give it that. It makes every second of life worth it, when you put everything on the line.
I know. That just means I can't afford to lose!
Well, nice work at dodging the attacks. Keep up the good work. Just don't rely too much on luck alone, please?
Don't know how. We're almost through this batch anyway. Just a little more!
@BATTLE
Don't worry, Captain. With enough guns and armor, I can make my own luck!
Just as long as you never stop.
Certainly a dark and cloudy day, ain't it?
"Cloudy" is one way to describe it. Stormy is the word I would use.
Yeah, it is a little rough now, but we'll make it through. So, want to see my latest cabaret sequence?
I'm not sure now is the best time.
Nonsense. Just watch me go!

Fields.MenuText: What if you slip on a puddle?
I didn't expect you to enjoy weather like this.
Sure, let's see what you have in store for us.

Fields.DialogueText: Then I'll just weave that into the dance routine. Legs and feet are just as useful as arms and hands!
I don't, but that's exactly the point. You can't let yourself get gloomy on days like this. You have to put on extra cheer to show that nothing can push you down.
Here goes! And take notes. I want to know just how alluring I am!
It's just too bad that those thunderclaps drowned out your last chorus.
Actually, I think that was something else. It looks like some Morganas are trying to upstage me!
Can't be done. Let's give them an encore.
@BATTLE
Whew! So how was that?
Dancing's all about control. When you know how and where you move, you can look just like you're wild and crazy... and that's when you strike!
Intense! With how close you got, I thought for sure you'd hit me.
A little like gambling, isn't it?
Exactly! Watch out, Captain – I might just dance your heart right into my purse!
Nuts! It looks like we really got into a jam this time.
You're telling me! This blockade looks sturdier than the Hoover Dam.
I told you it might be a trap.
I agreed with you, remember?
Then why did you still charge in?
Taking a gamble. Why else?
But I suppose we had no choice. The Morganas have to go.
And we've got to send them away! Got any orders for me?

Fields.MenuText: Give it all you've got. Enough force can break any dam.
Cover for the others so we can close in.
See if you can spot a weak point.

Fields.DialogueText: That's right. Time to bring it down!
Don't worry. Leave it to invincible Nevada to keep you all safe!
You have the mind of a miner, Captain. Find just the right place to strike, and everything falls into place.
I think we've got this now, Captain!
Great! Just don't get cocky.
I'm always cocky. It never stopped us before!
@BATTLE
*sigh*
Howdy, Captain! See my latest cross stitch?
Nice needlework. Is that a bluebird?
A mountain bluebird, to be more exact. My favorite kind of bird.
Oh, really?
Yep! Isn't it cute?

Fields.MenuText: I just always thought that your favorite would be something bigger, like a vulture or hawk.
For someone who does not like water, you sure like the color blue.
It's really going to brighten the place up!

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe in a more fighting mood. If I were to do one of these with Morganas around...
Water's only blue when there's a lot of it. The sky, on the other hand, is blue on a clear day, as you gaze up on it and drive into the vast horizon. That's why I love the bluebird.
Thanks. They have a most beautiful song they perform just after dawn. Perhaps I should try singing then, too.
Sometimes I just want to soar over the mountains where I come from.
You have a way of making the impossible happen. I can't wait to see you up there.
Captain...
*ALARM*
You Morganas, on the other hands, are the least favorite thing on every one of my lists!
Mine, too. Time for a war dance?
@BATTLE
No.
Only joking, Captain! Though I can bust out some mean embroidery with one eye on the sea.
That would be nice, once in a while. Just as long as we can still sleep if we want to.
With my guns for percussion!
Nevada, what's with all these shots being fired?! Are we under attack again?
Nope, just trying some trick shots with my guns.
Wait... Are those some of the dinner plates that you're flinging off the ship like clay pigeons?
Yep! And then I try to shoot them down before they hit the water. Pretty neat, huh?
Neat isn't exactly the word I would use for this. Aren't there quieter ways you can practice your marksman skills?
Well, this isn't all just for the war. It's also for show. I thought that this would be a fun sort of Wild West act I could do.

Fields.MenuText: I'm just worried that it will make people let their guard down when an actual battle starts.
Nevada, if you keep throwing away those plates, we won't be able to serve food. Not even your special recipes.
Maybe we can find an easier way for you to practice. But I agree, it would be a nice act.

Fields.DialogueText: I'd say that people should know how to differentiate different kinds of explosions, but I guess you're right.
Oh, hell, that would be terrible. I'll find something else to shoot... but it'll have to fly just as well as these plates!
Yeah, this is a little over the top even for me. Glad you like the overall idea, though.
*BOOM*
That wasn't me! It's coming from further away.
Ah, dammit.
Looks like we've stumbled into a turkey shoot. I'll show you just how well I've practiced!
@BATTLE
Nevada, seriously, that's enough.
Hold it! Stop! Come here! Shoot, how hard can it be to catch a few birds?
Why are you trying to catch seagulls?
For their feathers.
Huh? Why do you want their feathers?
I want to make another feathered headdress for my dances, but I want one that's personal. Something that says "me." So I thought, why not collect some in my travels?

Fields.MenuText: Well, please try not to hurt the birds.
Given how much you love to travel the world, your headpiece is certainly going to be colorful in the end.
At least you're not doing something really crazy. At first, I was worried that you were going to tar them onto yourself and try to fly.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. I don't want anyone to get hurt. Oh, well, I can just pick up feathers that fall on the deck.
That's why I'm so excited about this. I can decorate it more and more with mementos from around the world. Birds are world-class travelers too, so that's double the mileage.
Now that you mention it, I was trying to come up with another airborne solution for traveling inland...
Looks like things are coming along well. I can't wait to see you dance with it when you're done.
Thank you, Captain. I'll do a special routine just for you.
Wait, why are there so many birds here? Darn, I forgot! With so many birds on the move, something must have already riled them up.
Something like Morganas. Let's kill and keep moving!
@BATTLE
Oh, brother, here we go again...
You'll just have to wait and see!
How special are we talking?
Nevada, what are all these nets you're strewing about the ship? If you're still in that fishing contest with Oklahoma, this is taking it a little too far.
This isn't to catch fish. It's for flying things.
Birds?
No, but you got the first letter right. Baseballs.
Um, you're going to need to explain that a little more.
But we American Belles have a little trouble with home runs, you know? Actually, it's kind of the opposite. To be more precise, we put a lot of oomph into them, so they fly like torpedoes.
I've noticed that. Especially when that one ball nearly conked me on the head.
I said I was sorry about that. Anyway, they almost always fly out of the park and into the water.
So you're trying to snag the balls and keep them from getting lost at sea?
You have a keen eye, sugar... Sir! Think you can help me straighten out the nets on the port side?

Fields.MenuText: Well, at least it ought to keep people from falling overboard too.
Maybe you should focus more on moderating your attacks... I mean throws and bats.
Is the expense of maintaining all these nets worth saving a few baseballs?

Fields.DialogueText: Huh? Oh, yeah, that too!
You're supposed to do your best at these games. It's really spectacular when the balls go whizzing away, right?
Baseballs are magnificent treasures, Captain. Each one has its individual history of triumphs and defeats, and each bruise tells a story.
Look, I don't know if this will work on a warship all the time. The nets are a nice idea, but we need the manpower elsewhere.
Well, it was worth a shot. Would've needed to take it down anyway.
Why? Oh, don't tell me...
Yep. Morganas.
Take down this netting and get ready for action.
@BATTLE
Sometimes you just need to bask in the praise...
Yes. It's especially exciting when they make people jump for cover.
You know how I can appear wherever I want on the ship. Sometimes I pitch to myself to stay sharp.
You've certainly helped me write a few.
Now there's nothing protecting them from my line drives!
Thanks for agreeing to play blackjack with me.
It's my pleasure. You deal first, right?
Yep. It's the strangest thing... nobody will play with me lately.
A queen, eh? Hit me.
Ooh, looks like a bust. I win!
Already?
That's how the luck goes sometimes. Want to do another round?

Fields.MenuText: You sure you didn't cheat?
Maybe not. Luck just isn't with me today.
Sure, one more round.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course not! How could you say that? A gamble is worthless if you know how it's going to shake out.
Don't say that, Captain. Luck comes and goes like the wind. There are days that I am really lucky, and other times everything goes wrong. You just have to keep playing 'til you win.
Great! I won't go easy on you, though.
Well, now, this looks like a strong round.
Uh-oh.
Don't worry, Nevada, I won't clean you out.
That's not what I meant. A Morgana squadron is on its way.
Of course! I should have known my luck wouldn't hold out.
Look on the bright side! The real unlucky ones are the Morganas for stumbling into us.
@BATTLE
I'm sorry, Nevada. I shouldn't have said that.
It's okay. One more round, please?
Okay.
You're right. I feel lucky now. Let's do this!
That's the spirit.
I wouldn't expect it any other way.
Come on, come on! I don't have time for this!
Nevada, what's taking you? We're almost to the staging point, so your guns need to be ready.
Just a little longer! One of the boilers is giving me sass again, and I need to fix 'er up if I want to get anything done in the fight.
How much longer do you need?
A couple of minutes, maybe. Oh, I don't know. I'm sorry to worry you, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Don't be so hard on yourself. Luck comes and goes, you know?
Hang in there, Nevada. I'm still here for you, no matter what.
You can get done in time – I believe in you.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. What really matters is to not give up, no matter which way the dice fall.
Thanks. I'll be done in a jiffy.
Thank you. That means a lot to me. I won't let you down!
... There! Everything's ready to go! Gosh, I feel better already.
And just in time, too. See, everything worked out.
Of course it did. I'm the invincible gambler from the desert. Nothing can slow me down.
I'm learning from a master. Let's do this!
@BATTLE
Snake eyes on that pun, Captain! But I appreciate it. You're no slouch yourself at the old felt-topped table.
That's right. Everyone has a run of bad luck now and again. What's important is how you roll with the... rolls.
Captain! Captain! I have a big problem!
What's wrong, Nevada?
I lost my lucky pair of dice.
Okay. Walk it back. When did you see them last?
I don't know! I was just going to juggle them around a little for some fortune-telling, but when I checked my pockets, they were gone!

Fields.MenuText: Don't worry. I'll help you find them.
Calm down and focus. What was the last thing you remember doing with them?
I can buy you a new pair the next time we have shore leave.

Fields.DialogueText: We'd have a better chance of finding them if we had them... and then we wouldn't need to find them!
Right, right! Got to think straight about this. Hmm...
Yeah, but that wouldn't be the same. Not that I wouldn't treasure a gift from you – that would be wonderful – but these dice mean a lot to me!
Now that I think about it some more, the last time I saw them was...
What? Do you remember now?
Yeah... I wanted to show them to you, but you weren't in your office. Then we got into a battle with some Morganas, so I set them down...
Go check my quarters again.
Hold on... Yes! Thank you, Captain.
You're welcome. Just try to keep better track of your things, okay?
Like a hawk. Luck's always on my side, good or bad... but I prefer the good kind.
@BATTLE
We'll figure it out. I know that it means a lot to you.
Thank you.
I understand. I'll do what I can to help.
Oh my darling, oh my darling, oh my darling... Captain... Damn, just doesn't work.
What are you making? It looks like... some sort of spiral shape? Is this supposed to be an ammonite fossil?
No, though I might want to go fossil hunting later. This is a special sort of headgear I'm working on.
What sort of headgear? It kind of looks like the horns you'd see on a big sheep.
A bighorn sheep, to be exact. I'm trying to imitate their natural flair and make my own ram horns.
That would certainly make for a... Unique hat.
More like a helmet– just what I need for the tight scrapes we get into. What do you think?

Fields.MenuText: What materials are you using to make it?
Just make sure that your horns don't get snagged on something.
They really look nice on you.

Fields.DialogueText: Just a little bit of everything I could find. I don't want to use real horns, so I had to make do with what I have. Steel, concrete, sandstone...
Don't worry! An agile and lucky gal like me has nothing to worry abo – what are you doing, Captain, lying around on the floor like that?
Well, thank you kindly! Enough sugar and you might just tip the scales in your favor next game.
It looks pretty good, though I'm not sure how it will fare in combat.
I'd rather break a shell with it than with my head!
You're right. There they are. Sometimes, these Morganas are like stubborn, ornery goats themselves.
@BATTLE
I had to duck when your horns nearly "rammed" into me.
You call my name?
Gah! Captain, not while I'm chiseling!
Let's see, how would it work? It must be all in the wrists...
What's with the bullseye target? Trying to do some more target practice or dart throwing?
Almost. I'm trying a little card trick.
What do cards have to do with a dart board?
That's what I'm trying to find out. You see, I was practicing some trick shuffles and I started thinking. Wouldn't it be neat if I could throw cards like they were weapons?
Is that even possible?
Won't know until I try.

Fields.MenuText: They'd need to be custom designed, so they don't burn up in the process, or fail to make a dent.
You'd run out of cards fast.
That would give a unique flair to your fighting style.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point, but I can work on that. How hard can it be?
Just means that I'll have to make every shot count. I know how to conserve resources for the long run.
Thanks. I really got excited when I first thought of the possibility.
The only problem I see is that it won't work that well against our main enemy – the Morganas.
Unless I had truly amazing aim. Which isn't impossible in the long run, but... Hmm. What if I made giant-sized cards?
Well, an ace or royal flush would definitely be welcome right now. That fleet looks imposing.
No need to worry. A few well-aimed strikes, and we'll send this house of cards crashing down!
@BATTLE
Oh, solo mio! Solo duo!
What are you doing?
Ah, sorry, Captain! I was trying to sing some Italian verses. Not my usual forte, so please forgive me being off-key.
That's all right. It just surprised me a little. They do cabarets in Italy, too?
Maybe, I'll need to check. This was for a more personal reason.
What do you mean?
Italians form a key part of my state's immigrant population, so I thought I should look into some of the mother country's history.
I see. How's that coming along?
Okay. I have some background info, but I also want to pick up some of the foreign culture. If I can learn Parisian cabaret, I certainly can do the same for other cultures.

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps you should try piloting a gondola.
Have you tried making pizza?
Going to start growing an olive grove, then?

Fields.DialogueText: You know I hate water! I guess I'll have to get past that issue. Italy is a peninsula, after all.
No, but I intend to give it my best shot. I wonder if I could make a roulette wheel with some red sauce and black olives...
Excellent idea! We could always use more wine on the ship.
Maybe we can visit Italy during the road trip.
That would be great! I hear they do some crazy racing in the streets down there.
Just as long as you don't wreck any monuments in the process.
Those roads in Rome are as skinny as anything. At least I can deal with these Morganas by blasting them...
@BATTLE
That was a joke.
Too late!
Darn it, that wave splashed all over the deck.
These things happen at sea. Nothing we can do about them.
You can't just let things happen to you, Captain. Bad luck can turn into good luck if you just power through it!
I suppose it did help you cool off, right?
Well, I was enjoying this hot and dry day before that typhoon came along.

Fields.MenuText: Are you going to let a few waves get the best of you?
Here's a towel so you can dry off.
Water is essential for life, you know, even in a desert.

Fields.DialogueText: No way! I'm stronger than that. I'll be high and dry in no time. You'll see.
Thanks, but what about your own uniform?
Oh, I know. But it doesn't have to be everywhere!
It is rather curious that the waves are so unruly today. There's barely a breeze, and... wait.
You've got a keen sense for danger, Captain. There's a whole bunch of them shaking things up over to the starboard side.
They should learn that if you make waves, you might just get sunk yourself.
@BATTLE
I'll be fine. Battle has a way of drying me right up.
But it's sure making me think about draining the sea again.
*ALARM*
I knew it! General quarters, now!
Come one, come all, and the great Nevada will share the secrets of the desert with you.
What are you up to?
I've been thinking about luck lately, good and bad. I've had my share of both. But what makes it luck in the first place?

Fields.MenuText: Hmm... I'd say uncertainty. You don't know what's good or bad until it's right on top of you.
Taking a big risk.
The fact that it's a game.

Fields.DialogueText: That's exactly what makes it a gamble! Well done, Captain.
Close! It doesn't even have to be a big wager, but the fact that you might lose is what it's all about. You just don't know how the dice will fall.
Well, anything can be a game depending on how you look at it. What makes it a gamble is the educated guess. You don't know how it'll all shake out until it does.
I thought uncertainty was your thing.
I'm fine not knowing everything. But if Okie wants me to flirt with omniscience, I guess it might be fun.
Well, let's look at it and see what it shows us.
Let's see... it's all distorted and flipped... you know how crystal works.
I suppose that explains the crystal ball.
Oklahoma sent it to me! It's a big old ball of quartz from her namesake.
I see... you. That must mean you're in my future.
Funny... I see you. Maybe you're in mine.
Well, we knew that. What do we need this old thing for?
Oh, Captain! We're just seeing our reflections.
I guess that means we make our own luck.
Well, this will certainly look nice on the bridge. Wait a minute... do you see that?
A Morgana. Several!
Is this what's in our future?
Wait... put the crystal down. See, they're right over there.
Guess this thing came in handy after all!
@BATTLE
Nevada... Why exactly are you sitting half-buried in a pile of sand?
I decided to take a sand bath. Sort of a way to feel like I'm back home.
How's it working out for you?
Pretty nice for the first try. Probably would work better with genuine desert sand, but not half bad. Want to try it out, too?

Fields.MenuText: Actually, want to build a sandcastle?
Thank goodness you're okay. I was worried you had somehow gotten into quicksand.
Maybe, but I'm just a little anxious about getting my clothes all gritty.

Fields.DialogueText: That might be fun. I've never done that before.
Ha, ha, ha! Oh, Captain, you can be so silly sometimes. Though it would be kind of neat if I fossilized somehow. Nevada has a lot of fossils, but have you ever seen a fossil of Nevada?
Oh, it'll be fine. A little sand never hurt anyone. It's actually rather therapeutic, in my opinion.
Okay, I'll join in. ... Huh, it's kind of nice, in a way.
Yeah, some days it's nice to just sit back and relax, nothing to worry about. It makes me think of home, you know?
*ALARM*
Um, Nevada? How exactly are we going to get out of the sand?
Hmm... That is a bit of a dilemma. It wouldn't be so bad if this wasn't moist beach sand.
Just hurry and get us out! We have a fight on our hands.
@BATTLE
We'll get there, Nevada. I'll make sure of it.
That was a rough scrape back there. Are you okay, Nevada?
Decent enough. A few bruises, but nothing to trouble the invincible– Ow!
Are you sure? You shouldn't ignore your scrapes and bruises. What if you sank?
That's nothing to worry about. I'm more worried about what'll come when this is all over...
What do you mean?
Oh, nothing, nothing you need to worry about, sir.
No, this is clearly bothering you. What's wrong?
It's just... I don't know what will happen to me after the war.
That's the gamble. We have a road trip planned and everything...
No, what I mean is to me as a ship. I'm getting old for a ship, I know that. And when a mine loses its shine, you let the desert claim it.
Nevada...
Sure, I may be invincible on the battlefield, but what good does that do me when the war ends? Doesn't the Navy decide when I've had enough?

Fields.MenuText: You're not a tool anymore, Nevada. You're your own person, so stand up for yourself.
Stay strong, Nevada. You're not just invincible on the battlefield. You have a way of fighting for impossible dreams, so don't give up now.
I – and all your friends – will be with you until the end. We'll decide when and where and what that end will be. Together.

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks. It... Feels good to be treated like a real, living being.
You're right. I won't give up on my dreams, no matter what!
Thank you. I'll believe in everyone, too.
Anyway, I'm glad you shared your concerns with me. I'm listening. And if we have anything to say about it, so is the Navy.
Yeah. Thanks for being there with me. My odds look a lot cleaner with you in my corner, you know?
Just remember that you always have people there for you – not just me, but your sisters. Even Oklahoma.
You're right. No use getting worried about the future. I just have to put all my money on our teamwork fixing things in the end. That's where the payoff is.
The fact that it makes you feel good just shows that you already are real... And lovely to boot.
What the hell was that just now!?
Lady Luck rides again, Captain! I felt the wind on that shell... Good thing, too. It's hot out here.
@BATTLE
The Morganas sure have set up a swell welcoming party for us this time.
That's one way to look at it. Hold the line. We can't let them through!
Come on, it's just like a big celebration! Loud music, fireworks, crazy dancing – I mean, maneuvering...
I would appreciate the festivities more if we were not the hors d'oeuvres. And besides, you said that no party should be without singing, right? At least there's none of that.
Hey, great idea! Why don't I do a little cabaret performance?
Now?
No time like the present.

Fields.MenuText: I don't think that the Morganas will appreciate the entertainment.
Go for it. We could use the encouragement right now.
Just make sure you don't let up on the assault. We have to break through!

Fields.DialogueText: That's their problem, not mine.
Thanks! All right, here I go!
Don't worry, I'm giving them everything I've got! It's all or nothing in this fray!
@BATTLE
That's okay. My act was mainly for you and the troops. We need to keep a positive spirit to overcome those miserable Morganas.
Well, that's easy when you're dancing on top of the guns.
How could I not, Captain? I built my whole routine around them!
That was something else. Shame the Morganas were none too receptive.
Want to celebrate with a few relaxing rounds of blackjack?
Would if I could, but I'm missing a couple of aces.
Uh-oh. I'll help you look for them.
Oh, I know where they are. They're sticking out of a Morgana's clavicle.
You finally got that card-throwing trick down!
I told you I'd get it!
It's satisfying. I'm just going to need a replacement.
Guess you're not playing with a full deck.
You're lucky you're sweet, Captain, or you'd be next over the side.
My head is spinning...
What's with all the sea charts? You're usually more interested in road maps than where we are at sea.
Just trying to map out everywhere we've gone so far.
Why?
I thought it would be a way to better prepare myself for planning out our road trip.
How's that working out for you?
It's tough keeping track of where all we've gone. Maybe I'm coming at this from the wrong angle.

Fields.MenuText: Why don't you pretend that you're driving on the ocean floor when you're mapping out our travels? That might get you into the right mood.
Maybe you should just start with where we are now, to make things simpler.
Don't give up. I know you can get through this.

Fields.DialogueText: That would definitely make things more interesting. I could imagine us driving over huge mountains, or down a bottomless abyss. Too bad we can't really do that.
That might help. Thanks.
You're right! This little map will be a piece of cake for me!
I wouldn't stress about it.
I know, Captain. I just want to get it right. It's important to me.
It's important to me too. Whatever route we decide on, whatever end up happening, we'll make the best of it.
Just don't get started on that "drain the oceans" idea again, please.
But on the off chance that something goes wrong for you–
I'll be there with you. Nothing's wrong as long as that's the case.
Oh! Cards on the table, Captain... I feel the same way.
Looks like you've got a royal flush. That means you win.
I think we can split the pot on this one, Captain.
*ALARM*
Damn it! My luck's run out.
Mine's picked up. I was out of puns.
@BATTLE
Where is it, where is it!?
What's wrong? Did you lose your lucky dice again?
No, I lost my lucky coin!
I'll help you look for it. What kind of coin is it?
A penny, dated 1930.
A penny. That will be tough to find.
Well, I painted it red, white, and blue, so it is rather distinctive.

Fields.MenuText: What makes that penny so lucky to you?
Cheer up! It's lucky, and you're lucky. So, the two of you are bound to find each other again, right?
Don't worry. Even if you lose your luck, you're still you, right?

Fields.DialogueText: It got lost inside me when I was being refitted in Norfolk– a couple of workers flipped it for a bet. So when I awoke for the first time, it was already there with me.
You're right. Luck is like a wheel– even when it spins off course, it always arrives back where it belongs with new stories to tell!
Good point. A gambler never gives up – not even if her luck deserts her. You can't make me throw in the cards that easily.
Nevada, I think I found it.
Thanks. It's such a small thing, really.
It still has its own value.
You're right. I'm not sure if it is really lucky or not, but it's a part of my life, a precious treasure.
Well, hang onto it tight, because things are going to get rough again.
@BATTLE
I see. Well, I'll do everything I can to get it back to you.
I'll hang on to you too, Captain. Long as we're sticking to good luck charms...
Hey there. Nice out, isn't it?
Good enough for a painting.
Heh, thanks. I thought I'd try my hand at getting this one down on paper.
I guess we both have a knack for capturing pretty things.
Keep those coming, Captain, the worse the better. You're charging up my good luck.
Like your spiced foods? I get kind of burnt up at first, but I really enjoy the way you keep me guessing.
Well, then... I hope this next surprise works out, too.
Okay, what do you have in store for me this time? What gamble will I have to make?
Actually, it's a gamble that I am making, even if it scares me.
Huh?
Captain... I think it's time that you cooked me your favorite dish.

Fields.MenuText: Really? You trust me enough to try my cooking?

Fields.DialogueText: I want to give it a shot, and I would love to be a part of your interests. That is, if you're willing.
You're a lucky woman, Nevada, every darn time you make a bet. After all, this one was already in the bag for you.
You have this certainty about you, Captain... even when things aren't certain. And still you can surprise me.
Gambler's fallacy. These moments are independent events.
And we take the good with the bad. Not all of my surprises work out either.

Fields.MenuText: Now that's the ultimate gamble.
Why not your favorite?

Fields.DialogueText: Lucky for you a battleship likes things a little burnt.
Because this way it'll be a surprise.
There's nothing wrong with the occasional sure bet.
*ALARM*
Morganas. That reminds me – I picked up a new deck for you in port.
Thank you, Captain, but I'll keep it safe. This is just between you and me.
@BATTLE
